lexUnit.name: daddy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: (informal) one's father (common form by young children)

sentence.text: Then the path turns due north to the daddy of all potholes , Gaping Gill .
Read next week 's Cheers for a chance to win a bottle of claret and the daddy of all wine diaries the 1993 edition of the Grants of St James ' Wine Diary .
While she was doing so , she was company for little Sandy , who was just six months old and still in his pram , the image of his daddy , Bruce Mackenzie .
` He looked like one of those gipsies your daddy sent away this morning , Angela . "
` Oh Parr , my daddy 's not a terrorist , is he ? "
I can remember as a small child Daddy coming back from Barnard Castle with big loads on his bicycle .
I only wish Daddy could have seen me in the black lace dress .
` That must feel funny to see your daddy in a photograph . "
` He should have put on a pair of tights and joined his daddy in front of the fairy-lights . "
And ask them how they 'd answer their children 's inevitable questions , such as ` why do n't I have a daddy like the other kids at school ? "
I 'm not saying that she winds Daddy round her little finger , she does not .
What Daddy 's got are three cheap , shabby shops selling cheap , shabby suits to cheap shabby fools who would n't recognise a decent cloth if it were shoved down their throats .
` I 've never seen you smoke before , Daddy .
The daddy has a great interest in that kind of thing . "
I hear it was your birthday so I am sending you a photo of me and my daddy , Chris Geering , at Stratford-upon-Avon which was taken on my birthday .
I am going to ask Daddy to take me back home where I can go to work .
The aside to the children had no effect ; they wanted to be with their Big Daddy , and they would stay with him until he said ` no more " .
` Uncle Ross and I have been to see your mummy and daddy -- and they are going to be just fine . "
